basics.name: Carl V. Lewis
basics.label: Data Journalist/Information Designer/UX Consultant
basics.summary: A data-driven journalistic developer and designer, civic-tech entrepreneur, digital content strategist, former online editor/social media manager and Stanford Certified Project Manager with more than seven years of cumulative experience in digital content, data management and design.

work.summary:
-Won grant funding from the Collaborative Foundation to explore the feasibility of a geofenced peer-to-peer lending network.
-Project available online at staging.borrowly.com.
-Invited to train newsroom on data visualization best practices, and implement a workflow for data visualization within the site's CMS.

-Promoted to position in senior-level management focusing on shaping digital products that could yield higher consumer revenue. 
-Maintained previous job responsibilities as well.

-Led creation, design, development, staffing and launch of new digital alt-weekly product from Savannah Morning News.
-DoSavannah.com eclipsed its more established competitor alt-weekly by August.

-Oversaw content production, digital/social outreach and product development for savannahnow.com, dosavannah.com and other cross-platform company products, achieving a nearly 500 percent growth in social reach and a record 7 million monthly pageviews.
-Managed team of online producers/digital journalists; collaborated with traditional reporters and editors on optimizing print content for digital platforms; worked with marketing and sales departments to bridge the gap between editorial and sales in an ethical manner.
-Developed and executed growth strategies for company-wide social media platforms, including existing accounts on Facebook and Twitter and new accounts on Instagram, Vine, Tumb

-Built publication's website using a Twitter bootstrap template to create a custom WordPress theme.
-Grew monthly audience reach from 2,500 in print to 15,000-20,000 uniques as Digital Editor.

-Developed website and digital workflow for University of Oxford's official student newspaper.
-Edited news section both online and in print. Trained staffers.
